messages.content: The task list component needs to use React Query for server state management. We recently switched to TanStack Query. Keep Zustand just for client-side UI state.
Refactored the TaskList component to use React Query (TanStack Query) for fetching and caching tasks. Moved the filter/sort UI state to Zustand store. Clean separation now.
Perfect. For the API, make sure the task list endpoint uses cursor-based pagination with limit and cursor parameters. Not offset-based.
The endpoint already uses cursor-based pagination with limit and cursor params. The response includes next_cursor in the meta object. React Query's useInfiniteQuery handles it nicely.

Good. The response wrapper should have the standard format - data contains the items, meta contains pagination info and other metadata. All our endpoints use this {"data": ..., "meta": {...}} structure.
Verified the response format. It returns {"data": [...tasks], "meta": {"next_cursor": "...", "has_more": true}}. Consistent with all other endpoints.
We migrated some endpoints to GraphQL but kept REST for most things - it's a hybrid approach now. The React 18 concurrent features help with the GraphQL subscriptions for real-time updates.
The task sharing notifications use the GraphQL subscription on React 18. The concurrent rendering handles the streaming updates smoothly. REST endpoints remain for CRUD operations.
